Title: RM6263 Digital Specialist and Programmes
Description:
Crown Commercial Service (CCS) as the Authority has put in place a Pan Government Collaborative Agreement for the provision of Digital, Data and Technology (DDaT) specialists and facilitate large-scale digital transformation programmes to be utilised by Central Government Departments and all other UK Public Sector Bodies, including Local Authorities, Health, Police, Fire and Rescue, Education and Devolved Administrations.

The lotting structure of this framework is as follows:
Lot 1 - Digital Programmes
Lot 2 - Digital Specialists
Contact Name: The Minister for the Cabinet Office acting through Crown Commercial Service

Title: Free Schools Support Service
Description:
The Department for Education has awarded service contract for the provision of Free School Support Service.
The free school programme plays an important role in helping to deliver new, high-quality places of all types where they are needed most. Following the Spending Review, work is ongoing on a future programme and in due course, we will set out plans for delivering further special and AP free schools as part of the new investment of £2.6bn between 2022 and 2025, as well as for further mainstream schools.
It is expected that there will be a need for an external support service to include the following:
- Generate interest in new applications via the DfE-led free school application process, supporting groups to submit high-quality applications and providing support to applicant groups throughout the department's application and assessment process.
- Deliver a small number of free school information events on behalf of the Department for Education.
Region: North East,North West,Yorkshire and The Humber,East Midlands,West Midlands,East of England,London,South East,South West

Title: Analytical support to the Ministry of Energy
Description:
This project provides Ministry of Energy of Ukraine with required additional capacity to react on the increasing number of issues and solve all tasks related to the existing and potential consequences of the Russian invasion as well as to perform proactive communication with international partners. The expected outputs are:
•	Position on the international laws, treaties and legislation which were harassed following the Russian armed forces occupied Ukrainian nuclear power plants 
•	Assistance in drafting talking points for the meeting of the deputy minister of energy with OECD and IEA
Supplier [Name|Address|Ref type|Ref Numb: [KPMG Ukraine LTD|32/2, Moskovska St., Kyiv, 01010, Ukraine|NONE_OTHER||No|No]

Title: Initial stage of economic assessment of Ukraine
Description:
The project is aimed at contributing to the initial stage of the discussion on rebuilding Ukraine's economic resilience to prevent people's suffering and deepening the poverty trap for an increasing number of vulnerable Ukrainian citizens. After the Russian invasion of Ukraine all economic positions, economy structures and the rules of the game on all levels have changed dramatically. The assets were damaged or destroyed, the exports and imports diminished, the human capital lost constituted millions of people to war and migration, size of vulnerable groups increased dramatically, and humanitarian needs skyrocketed. The expected output results are as follows:
•	A research brief on the rapid economic assessment
•	Presentation of the findings of the brief
•	Opinion editorials, articles and comments in the media
Supplier [Name|Address|Ref type|Ref Numb: [Centre for Economic Strategy|02000, 36D Saksaganskoho street, Kyiv, Ukraine|NONE_OTHER||Yes|No]

Description:
This tender is being run as a Competitive Dialogue with Negotiation.\r
\r
The future solution must include delivery, installation, training and support. The software system must have multi-venue and multi-event type capabilities, customer relationship management and a flexible but comprehensive marketing functionality.\r
\r
The Company wish to explore a white label ticketing solution and potentially enter into an agreement with a supplier who can offer software to allow the Company to effectively manage and run their own ticketing system.\r
\r
The Company would consider an amalgamation of both of the above if available.\r
\r
It is anticipated that the contract will run from 1/4/2022 - 31/3/2025 - with the option to extend for a further 1 plus 1 year.\r

Title: SPS 2523 - Emergency Electrical Submain 24/7 Call Out, Repair and Authorised Works
Description:
The Royal Borough of Greenwich (the Royal Borough) is pleased to offer an opportunity for Contractors to provide a tender for an Emergency Electrical sub main 24/7 Call out, Repair Service and One-off Installation Works as instructed which must be received by the Royal Borough by no later than 12.00 on 23 December 2021. The contract period will be for four years with an option on the Council to extend for a further two years. The procurement seeks prices for carrying out to the Royal Borough's Housing Dwellings and associated Communal and Landlord's areas:

a)	An Electrical sub-main Emergency Callout and Repair with attendance times during normal working hours of within two hours and out of hours of within three hours.
b)	One-off Electrical Rewire Installations as instructed.

All in accordance with the requirements of the IET BS 7671 Wiring Regulations 18th Edition A1.

The deadline for clarification questions is 16th December 2021. The deadline for tender submissions is Thursday 23rd December 2021 at 12PM UK Local Time.  Full description of the tender and access to the tender documents can be found in the link below: https://procontract.due-north.com/Opportunities/Index?resetFilter=True&applyFilter=True&p=2241eb95-058a-e511-80f7-000c29c9ba21&v=1

Notice Identifier: Delivery of a Wheeled Sports Facility in Cranbrook, Devon
Title: Delivery of a Wheeled Sports Facility in Cranrbook, Devon
Description:
A consortium of developers, the East Devon New Community Partners, is delivering the currently consented first 3,500 homes at Cranbrook in East Devon. The Section 106 agreement relating to this development secures the preparation and servicing of land for a "Skateboard Park" prior to 2,250 dwelling occupations. The responsibility for the delivery of the skatepark transferred to the Town Council earlier in 2021. Cranbrook Town Council is now looking to appoint a preferred supplier for the construction of a wheeled sports facility in a town centre location in Cranbrook as set out in the tender documents.

Any prospective supplier is invited to submit their design proposal(s) in accordance with the specification set out in the tender documents to the Town Council.

Title: Adult ADHD Assessment, Treatment and Review Service in Thurrock
Description:
This Notice is to inform the market of the decision of NHS Mid and South Essex Integrated Care Board (The Authority) to award a contract to Provide Wellbeing CIC to deliver an ADHD Assessment, Treatment and Review Service across the Thurrock locality.

Provide Wellbeing CIC are commissioned by the Authority to assess, treat and review patients for ADHD where there there has been a back-log back of adults awaiting ADHD assessment and treatment. There are over 300 patients in Mid and South Essex who have been waiting for an ADHD assessment and any necessary treatment for between one and two years. ADHD is a recognised neurodevelopmental disorder characterised by hyperactivity, impulsivity and inattention. 

The purpose of the expansion of this service is to commission Provide CIC to provide a full ADHD assessment and treatment pathway for patients within the Thurrock locality, who had been awaiting service provision for their mental health needs. This service will ensure an equitable service offer, ensuring that patients who have waited for access to care for at least 12 months will be able to access this urgent mental health care and treatment within the Thurrock locality. The contract is for a short term, non-recurrent contract, with a total contract term of 12 months, commencing 1st April 2022 and expiring on the 31st March 2023, at a total aggregate value of £237,000 (including VAT).

Due to transformation, capacity pressures and moving towards an ICS, this retrospective notice is published in line with the dates of awarded governance and contract signatures being obtained. 

The Authority is publishing this Contract Award Notice in the Contracts Finder in accordance with the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (as amended by The Public Procurement (Amendment etc.) (EU Exit) Regulations 2020) for spend above £25,000. The Services in scope of this Contract Award Notice fall within 'social and other specific services' within the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (as amended by The Public Procurement (Amendment etc.) (EU Exit) Regulations 2020), but the total contract value does not exceed the current threshold of £663,540.

Title: Statistical Business Register
Description:
PLEASE NOTE THIS IS A RESTICTED  ADVERT FOR THOSE SUCCESSFULLY DOWNSLECETD FROM THE INITAL TENDER STAGE OF THE CCS FRAMEWORK - DIGITAL OUTCOMES AND SPECIALSTS  5 (DOS5) RM1043.7 - DIGITAL OUTCOMES 

https://www.digitalmarketplace.service.gov.uk/digital-outcomes-and-specialists/opportunities/16546

The Office for National Statistics (Contracting Authority) is the UK's largest independent producer of official statistics and is recognised as a national statistical institute (NSI).  It is responsible for collecting and publishing statistics related to the economy, population, and society at national, regional, and local levels. It also conducts the Census for England and Wales every 10 years.

Its main responsibilities are:

•	the collection, compilation, analysis, and dissemination of a range of key economic, social, and demographic statistics about the UK
•	the provision of statistical leadership and methodological advice for the benefit of UK official statistics and
•	representation of the UK internationally as the NSI. 
In order to collect data for the above purposes, surveys are carried out throughout the year and maintaining an accurate database of participants, such as the Statistical Business Register (SBR), is key to doing that successfully.

The main objective of this tender exercise is to engage a supplier to develop and deliver a new Statistical Business Register (SBR) by March 2023. The expected outcomes are:

•	To replace parts of an ageing legacy solution (IDBR - Inter-Departmental Business Register), which constrains the business in reacting to new requirements
•	To provide an improved service to both internal and external users of the existing Business Register (IDBR) by providing a more flexible, self-serve product.

Title: EV Charging Points
Description:
Introduction The University is seeking to install electric vehicle charging across it's Estate and to two sites of Buxton & Leek College covering Derbyshire & Staffordshire.

Following an initial scoping exercise covering staff and students there is evidently demand for EV charging in small amounts at every site however clearly there is greatest demand at the main Hubs for Higher Education teaching at Kedleston Road and other Derby City sites.

To demonstrate commitment to low and zero emission vehicles the University intends to install charging points to the majority of Academic, Commercial & Residential properties under it's control over the next 3 years in a phased manner.

In addition to controlled-access 'public' charging proposed, the University operates it's own fleet of maintenance vehicles which are shortly to be exchanged for wholly electrified vans and a small fleet of pool cars which will be exchanged for electric or plug-in hybrid electric vehicles in the next 12 months.

The location priority list given in the following section identifies the preferred order of installation along with pertinent site-specific information to assist production of a quotation. Individual system design & installation will be the responsibility of the supplier who shall demonstrate suitable skills & experience in this field as part of the procurement process.

Equipment requirements & Tariff management requirements are outline at this stage and may be subject to variation as part of consultancy advice to be provided as part of the system design.

Title: Medical Assessments: Vaccine Damage Payment Scheme
Description:
Contract for the provision of medical assessments in relation to the Vaccine Damage Payment Scheme (VDPS). Further information on the scheme can be found here https://www.gov.uk/vaccine-damage-payment/eligibility

The services required are for Medical Assessments of the evidence being presented by applicants making a claim under the VDPS. An 'Assessment' is the end-to-end process to assess causation and level of disablement against the medical evidence presented in relation to a Claimant's health condition and/or disability.

The Supplier is required to undertake all appropriate action to complete the assessment. This may include gathering evidence from the most appropriate source/reference/expert/specialist to ensure a definitive view can be provided.

Historically, the average number of annual assessments is c100 however volumes have increased following the addition of Covid and Adult Flu vaccinations to the VDPS. There is no minimum (or maximum) commitment to the number of assessments that will be required under the contract as the scheme is demand driven. It is estimated that in year one of the contract there will be c1500-1800 claims that will require assessment within the first year of the contract. It is estimated that after year 1 of the contract the number of assessments will between 100-1000 assessments will be required per annum.

The estimated value of the contract set out here in and in the Contract Notice (FTS reference 2021/S 000-028514) was 6000000GBP ex VAT.  This estimate could be affected by the variable volume of assessments required over the term of the Contract and the value could therefore be more or less that the amount stated.

Contract can be extended by 2 x 12 month periods up to 20/03/2028 and 20/03/2029.
Contact Address 1: Stella House, Goldcrest Way, Newburn Riverside

Title: Welfare Benefits and Tribunal Service
Description:
Doncaster Borough Council ("the council") invites detailed proposals for the provision of a Welfare Benefits and Tribunal service for the Doncaster area. 

The primary purpose of this Service will be to support adults with multiple and complex needs who have a disability or long term health condition and their carers with welfare benefits and tribunal representation.  The aim is to ensure that these people are aware of and are able to take up their rights to welfare benefits, thereby maximising their income and improving their independence and choice.

The focus of the Service is to support individuals with multiple and complex needs to maximise their income which, in turn, will help to maintain or improve their independence, health and wellbeing and improve their life choices. 

The Service aim is to focus on those individuals who may not have the ability to navigate the benefits system and online and other digital technology to make a benefits claim.

The Service will actively promote independence and self-help to those people who have resilience and ability to navigate the benefits system themselves via digital methods and or other community based support, for example libraries.

It is anticipated that the contract will commence on 01/04/2022 and run for a period of 3 years. There is also an option to extend the contract by a further 12 month period at the sole discretion of the council.

Title: Bespoke design, build and maintenance (including updates) of trial specific pathway for BASIS within the British Spine Registry. This will allow direct data capture of research data as well as electronic consent for participation in the BASIS trial
Description: The BASIS study is a clinical trial, funded by the NIHR HTA programme, aiming to investigate whether night time bracing is as good as full time bracing for patients with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis. The study involves around 20 UK NHS hospital trusts, and is coordinated by the Sheffield CTRU at the University of Sheffield, with Sheffield Children's Hospital as the lead site and Sponsor. At all participating NHS centres, there will be multiple consultants, spinal nurses, research nurses and orthotists involved in the study, and the study is being conducted mostly through electronic methods. Most UK spinal consultants and specialist nurses already use the British Spine Registry in their clinical work. It was therefore agreed at the point the funding application was made, that the British Spine Registry (provided by Amplitude) would be used for the electronic data collection and electronic consent for the BASIS study. As Amplitude could provide the required system within a similar cost profile to the UoS system "Prospect" that is mostly used in CTRU studies, and because most clinicians involved in the study are already familiar with the system, it was agreed that this would be used for BASIS, and alternatives did not need to be considered.

Title: Framework agreement to supply ICT goods and services to the education sector and any UK public sector body - Phase 1
Description: Academies Enterprise Trust (AET) and The Elliot Foundation Trust (TEFAT) seek to establish a framework agreement enabling schools, multi-academy trusts and all UK public sector bodies to procure a variety of ICT goods and services, where those goods and services are split into a series of lots and possibly sub-lots, allowing suppliers to respond to single lots/sub-lots, multiple lots/sub-lots, or all lots. The lots range from hardware and software purchases, to procuring a full managed service with a chosen Strategic ICT Partner. There is no limit to the number of suppliers on each lot and no limit to the number of lots you can respond to. We welcome responses from registered companies (including SMEs), consortia, Special Purpose Vehicles and Voluntary Community and Social Enterprise (VCSEs).The Sponsors (AET and TEFAT) will be procuring a Strategic Partner utilising the framework, which will run in parallel to the framework procurement. These further competitions will be lots 16 and 17 of the framework ITT.The lots for this phase of the ICT Framework Procurement are Strategic Partnering Services, Support Services, the AET Further Competition, and the TEFAT Further Competition.enFrame are focussed on ensuring that every procurement is driven by Social Value and fighting climate change, an ethos that is shared with AET and TEFAT. A such, the framework asks what Social Value supplies can offer through delivery of the service that would benefit the trusts, and what they can offer and do to reduce the trusts' carbon footprint.

Title: Secondment of a Principal Capital Mechanical Engineering Consultant
Description: Merseytravel would like to appoint a Principal Capital Mechanical Engineering Consultant on a secondment for an initial period of 12 months. Reporting to the Technical Services Manager, the post holder will oversee and support delivery of a wide programme of short and long term works including small and large infrastructure refurbishment and deliver the development and implementation of capital programme projects supported by the Senior Capital Mechanical Engineering Consultant, while meeting budget, quality, environmental, and health and safety standards. Title: Piled Reinforced Concrete Raft Underpinning - Belmont Place and Noakes Meadow, Ashford, Kent
Description:
Ashford Borough Council is seeking suitably experienced contractors to carry out piled reinforced concrete raft partial underpinning to a two storey block of flats at Belmont Place and to an attached two storey house at Noakes Meadow.

Contractors must be approved members of Association of Specialist Underpinning Contractors "ASUC".

Work to include: 

Belmont Place: 
Piles 19 nr.
Excavation - 46 m3
Concrete  - 31 m3

Noakes Meadow:
Piles 12 nr.
Excavation - 30 m3
Concrete - 20 m3

Term:
10 weeks from commencement.

Tender Evaluation:
70% Price 
30% Quality
•	Experience (specific works) 50%
•	Resident Liaison Plan 12.5%
•	Resources 12.5%
•	Managing Risks 12.5%
•	Zero Defects 12.5%
You will need to achieve a score of 60% or more for the project specific questions Q1-Q5 to be considered for further evaluation, and for the pricing element of your bid to be considered.

Contract Award:
The company who submits the most economically advantageous tender.

Form of Agreement:
JCT Minor Works Agreement 2016

Documents attached:
•	Tenderer's Checklist
•	Tender STRUC/21/1
•	Standard Selection Questionnaire 

Tender Return:
In order to be considered please register your interest on the Kent Business Portal and return your bid electronically through the portal no later than 10:00hrs on Monday 10th January 2022.

Documents to be returned
•	Tender STRUC/21/1
•	Standard Selection Questionnaire 
•	Quality Question Reponses
•	Method Statement

Timetable
Invitation to Tender:  	24th November 2021
Final Date for Clarification:	17:00hrs 10th December 2021
Tender Return Date:	10:00hrs 22nd December 2021
Evaluation of Bids:	w/c 27th December 2021 
Standstill Period:	10 calendar days
Appointment made:	w/c 10th January 2022
Commencement of Contract:	18th January 2022
Completion of Contract:	28th March 2022

Notes:
1) Please register your interest through the Kent Business Portal - we will use these registration details to inform you of any amendments, or items of clarification during the tender period. 
2) If you have any items of clarification during the tender period, these should be uploaded to the Kent Business Portal and a response will be provided.  
3) Please be aware that you need to download the documents attached to this advert and submit your bid electronically by the due date. Your registration of interest will NOT be used to issue you with tender documentation.
4) When submitting your bid, please keep additional marketing material to a minimum.
5) Please adhere to any page limit specified, and restrict the size of any uploaded document to less than 20Mb
6) The "Last date for Expressing Interest" detailed at the beginning of this notice, is the last date for submitting your bid.

Further Information
If you have any queries please contact planned.maintenance@ashford.gov.uk
Additional Text: The tender document and additional information can be accessed from the Kent Business Portal https://www.kentbusinessportal.org.uk/

Organisation Name: NHS SOUTH, CENTRAL AND WEST COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: Provision of Lloyd George Record Digitisation Services - Lot 1 - Scanning Services to NHS Leeds CCG and Calderdale Kirklees and Wakefield CCGs
Description:
The LG patient record comprises of the LG envelope and the contents, which is an important part of the patient's historical medical record. Each Lloyd George envelope has a broad range of detailed personal information stored inside and maintaining the security accuracy, availability and integrity of these legacy records is vital. The handling of these records needs particular care; the paper records can be up to 70 years old and some records are fragile and in a poor state, coupled with the fact the information they hold is vital and paramount for safe medical practice. The lack of continuity and resilience within the paper record poses a risk to the ongoing, continuity of person-centred care.. There is a legal requirement to keep the full patients record for a minimum of 10 years after the death of a patient.

There are four primary reasons for digitisation of Lloyd George records:
•	safer care for patients 
•	release of space within practices to provide additional consultation areas
•	access to the full patient record at the point of care
•	GP Contract commitments to digitise all Lloyd George patient records by March 2022.



This procurement followed a competitive tender using the NHS England and NHS Improvement Dynamic Purchasing System (DPS) (OJEU Reference 2020/S 152-373617) which was established by the NHS England and NHS Improvement National Commercial and Procurement Hub as a route to awarding contracts for Lloyd George Record Digitisation Services. It is compliant with the public procurement regulations and public authority standing financial instructions. To note, the tender is caught in the scope of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 - Regulation 34: Dynamic Purchasing Systems.

NHS Leeds CCG and Calderdale Kirklees and Wakefield Clinical Commissioning Groups have awarded a contract to deliver their Lloyd George Record Digitisation Services

This procurement process was facilitated by the NHS England National and Commercial Procurement Hub (commissioned from the SCW CSU) on behalf of the Commissioners.

[CIVICA UK LIMITED|Southbank Central,30 Stamford Street

GB|COMPANIES_HOUSE|01628868|Yes|No]

Title: London Breast Screening Workforce Leadership, Influencing & Service Improvement
Description:
To train members of London's breast screening workforce to become leaders and innovators within their organisations. Breast screening services face a number of challenges not only as a direct result of Covid-19 on provision but also because the pandemic has exposed frailties within the those services. Staff, both clinical and administrative, are stretched and recruitment and retention is challenging. Morale is low and staff are not always able to gain support from within their organisations to try to address these challenges.
NHSEI is looking to commission an evaluated training programme that will support current and future leaders of the London breast screening workforce to develop strong leadership, influencing and service improvement skills. We would like breast screening services to have staff, both clinical and non-clinical, who have the confidence, skills and knowledge to identify problems within their services and to be better equipped to confront them. This includes the ability to recognise issues as they arise, to develop plans and strategies to deal with those issues and to have the necessary skills to influence/challenge their organisations internally to acknowledge the issues and act upon them.
Supplier [Name|Address|Ref type|Ref Numb: [PA CONSULTING SERVICES LIMITED|10 Bressenden Place SW1E 5DN|NONE||No|No]

Title: Body Project / Positive Body Image Train the Trainers Programme
Description: The Body Project is an evidence-based eating disorder prevention programme designed to help adolescent girls and young women resist pressures from society to conform to unrealistic beauty and appearance standards. To date the Body Project has been used in schools, Universities, VCSE and community health services and delivered to over 4.5 million over 136 countries. It is a cognitive-dissonance-based intervention usually delivered to 8-12 individuals over a variety of formats/durations.

Description:
This award notice concerns the procurement of General Practice (GP) Services via an Alternative Provider Medical Services (APMS) contract for the Trowbridge Surgery, 18 Merriam Avenue, London, E9 5NE.

The Procurement exercise was conducted via Further Competition / Call-off procedure under NHS England's APMS Pseudo Dynamic Purchasing System (PDPS) (OJEU ref: 2020/S 016-034789).
London Shared Service) on behalf of the Authority, in connection with a competitive procurement exercise that was conducted in accordance with a process based on the Open Procedure under the Public Contract Regulations 2015 ("the Regulations" (as amended)).

The Service falls within the scope of the Light Touch Regime (LTR) - Section 7 (Reg 74-76) of the Regulations governing procurement of Health, Social and related services listed under Schedule 3 of the Regulations. None of the references to "Open procedure", "ITT", the use of the term "tender process", or any other indication shall be taken to mean that the Authority intends to hold itself bound to any of the Regulations, save those applicable to LTR provisions.

NHS England and NHS Improvement (NHSE/I) retains formal liability for the commissioning of primary medical care GP services and is therefore referenced as "the Authority" in this documentation; however, the decisions applicable to this Procurement will be made by North East London CCG (NEL CCG) in line with its Delegation Agreement with the Authority. In circumstances where a CCG has accepted fully delegated responsibility under co-commissioning, the CCG may be the signatory to the Contract on behalf of the Authority.

In line with the Health and Care Act 2022, the CCGs will be abolished and replaced by Integrated Care Boards (ICBs). Any reference to CCGs in this procurement should be interpreted as referring to the ICBs that will take their place in due course.

Title: 218_21 Specialist Vehicle Contract Hire/Leasing
Description:
A national multi-lot, multi-supplier framework agreement for medium to long term hire/lease of specialist vehicles:

Lot 1 - Refuse Collection Vehicles (RCV's)
Lot 2 - Compact sweepers
Lot 3 - Chassis mounted sweepers
Lot 4 - Winter maintenance vehicles
Lot 5 - Gully emptiers
Lot 6 - Minibuses
Lot 7 - Midibuses
Lot 8 - Buses & coaches
Lot 9 - Customised vehicles (eg. mobile libraries)
Lot 10 - Tippers
Lot 11 - Hook loaders
Lot 12 - Skip loaders

The framework agreement has the option to extend for up to a further 24 months. The total estimated value stated includes the option period.

To tender: (a) Go to www.eastmidstenders.org, (b) Register (c) Search for tender opportunity '218_21' d) Express an interest (e) Download the tender from the website.
Additional Text:
As a Central Purchasing Body as defined in the Public Contracts Regulations 2015, the Framework Agreement is open for use by Public Bodies (defined at https://www.espo.org/amfile/file/download/file/9608/) that also fall into one of the following classifications of user throughout all administrative regions of the UK: Local Authorities; Educational Establishments (including Academies); Central Government Departments and Agencies; Police, Fire & Rescue and Coastguard Emergency Services; NHS and HSC Bodies, including Ambulance Services; Registered Charities; Registered Social Landlords; The Corporate Office of the House of Lords, The Corporate Officer of the House of Commons; or any public body established by or under the Scotland Act 1998 or any Act of the Scottish Parliament. Details of the classification of end user establishments and geographical areas are available at: https://www.espo.org/legal.

ESPO has established a commercial trading company, ESPO Trading Limited, whose target clients are third sector organisations such as national and local charities, public sector mutual organisations and other organisations involved in the delivery of services to or for the public sector. The successful Supplier may be asked to enter into an additional separate framework agreement (the Second Framework) with ESPO Trading Limited on materially similar terms to that found in the tender pack to be entered into by ESPO itself.

Any Second Framework agreement will be a purely commercial agreement and will, for the avoidance of doubt, not be governed by the Public Contract Regulations 2015 or other public procurement legislation. ESPO Trading Limited may enter into the second framework agreement with the successful supplier and make it available to third sector clients who themselves are not required to follow the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 or other public procurement legislation. Accordingly, this is provided for bidders' information only.

An eAuction process may be used to award subsequent call off contracts following the reopening of competition among the parties to the Framework Agreement.

Title: Identity Access Management - Service Adoption and Enablement
Description:
The support required for this Call-Off is Data Management (and Similar) Services as per the DCfH service definitions.

The team will be responsible for taking products and services that are being delivered by delivery functions in the Identity and Access Management platform and identifying and supporting pilots of the products and services and then engaging with external stakeholders such as NHS organisations to ensure that they are adopted and used to realise expected outcomes and benefits. This will require the team to build solid working relationships with delivery teams, have a clear view of their scope of work, plans to deliver to expected outcomes. 1.	Refurbishment and decoration to the ground and first floor.
2.	New flooring throughout.
3.	Installation of new wayfinding signage and noticeboards to both floors.
4.	Removal of and reinstatement of partition walls to first floor.
5.	Installation of platform lift.
6.	Modification to existing staircase.
7.	Alterations to ground floor WC.
8.	Creation of new staff work room and store cupboard to ground floor.
9.	New WC and staff kitchen to first floor.
10.	Decoration and new flooring to first floor.
11.	M&E works in support of new layout/ furniture layout.
12.	Strip out of existing Data and CCTV cabling.
13.	Installation of Cat6a cabling/ containment for new IT and CCTV installations.
14.	Removal of redundant cabling and trunking.
15.	Plaster of affected areas.
16.	New lift installation
17.	Install new trunking and data cabling for IT and CCTV.
18.	Painting and decoration.
19.	Installation of new mechanical and electrical works
20.	Installation of new Accessible WC facilities to first floor.
21.	External decoration and new entrance signage
22.	Replace flat roof coverings and rainwater downpipes including new man safe system
23.	Overhaul and decorate external windows
24.	Lift and reinstate crazy paving at front and repoint. 
25.	Decorate metal railings and gate. 
26.	Replace defective paving slabs to external paths and walkways.
27.	Widen disabled ramp to make DDA compliant. 
28.	Installation of new radiant heat panels and boiler. 
29.	Installation of new LED based lighting throughout the ground and first floors. 
30.	Installation of Cat6a cabling/ containment for new IT and CCTV installations.

The detail scope of works and requirements are found in various parts (such as the Employers requirements and Preliminaries sections) of the tender documents.

Title: Beckenham Place Park East Restoration: Landscape Architecture/ Principal Designer/ Contract Administrator/Supervisor Services
Description:
Lewisham Council invites you to submit a  tender for the provision of Landscape Architecture/ Principal Designer/ Contract Administrator/Supervisor services for the regeneration of Beckenham Place Park East.  
The  consultant appointed will complete the technical design of the landscape and ensure all aspects of the scheme are delivered to a high quality through to handover and use. All duties, as set out by RIBA, associated with work stages 4 - 7 are expected to be undertaken by the consultant appointed. The Council is seeking a complete, 'end-to-end' package of consultancy services from design/tender stage right through to end of defects sign-off. Amongst other things, the multi-disciplinary team will be responsible for fulfilling the role of principal designer during pre-construction/demolition and the role of contract administrator during works, as well as preparing the specification for the works and assisting with the tender evaluation process.

Organisation Name: South London and Maudsley NHS Foundation Trust
Title: PAIN: EQUALITY OF CARE AND SUPPORT IN THE COMMUNITY (PEACS)
Description:
This project aims to co-develop and test a bio-psycho-social
approach in primary care to caring for people living with chronic pain. This approach will
include screening, GP consultation and support from a mental health practitioner and the
voluntary care sector. Chronic pain is one of the most common long-term conditions in
England, as well as locally in Lambeth. Research suggests that chronic pain is more prevalent
among people with Black backgrounds. There are also a range of factors that contribute to
inequalities of patient experience, access and health outcomes for this population. Effort will
go into outreach and engagement with people from Black communities to co-develop the
approach. Programme development will start in late 2021, with an aim to start using the digital
platform in March 2022.

Organisation Name: Joint Procurement Service for Surrey and Sussex Police
Title: Reboot - Sussex Early Intervention Youth Mentoring Programme
Description:
The Police and Crime Commissioner for Sussex (SPCC) is awarding a contract for the supply and delivery of a mentoring programme for the Sussex Early Intervention Reboot Programme, to include a one to one support package for children and young people aged 10-17 years old who are experiencing high risk factors that are associated with serious violence in Sussex. The aim is to identify children and young people at the earliest opportunity when first coming to the notice of police. The objective of the programme is to reduce the risk of those children and young people identified as becoming perpetrators of violence, crime, avoiding repeat victimisation and entering the criminal justice system. 

The contract has been awarded for a 12-month period, commencing on the 1 April 2022. The value of the contract £130,000, with the option to extend for a further 12 months subject to funding.

Title: Public and Patient Panel
Description:
The GDC has appointed an independent research organisation for it's  Public and Patient Panel 2022-2024 call off contract. There is no commitment to commission work underneath the panel , therefore the estimated value of the contract is £0 - 120k plus VAT.

The panel will enable the GDC to  involve and engage public and patients in a range of co-productive research and policy work.

The contract will run for 2 years from April 2022.

The overarching aims for the panel are: 

-	to provide access to a group or groups of patients and the public, some of whose knowledge and understanding of GDC and dental regulation develops over time; 

-	to ensure we reflect and harness the input of public and patients in as much of our work as is possible; and 

-	to provide a flexible, responsive and cost-effective method for GDC to engage patient and public in our work.

There are three main objectives for public and patient engagement in our work: 

-	to provide independently facilitated evidence about public views and perceptions of topical or current issues in dental regulation;

-	to provide independently facilitated public and patient views on their experience of the quality of dental services;

-	to obtain independently facilitated public and patient feedback about regulatory research and policy initiatives or communications being considered, developed or undertaken by the GDC.

Title: Council Tax, Benefits & Business Rates Services
Description:
To enhance and modernize the Council Services administering the billing, collection and recovery of Council Tax from over 99,000 households and Business Rates from approximately 5,800 businesses. Including calculating discounts, exemptions, rate reliefs and Business Improvement District charges in accordance with legislation and Council policies. Determine applications for Housing Benefits, Discretionary Housing Payments and Council Tax Support from new claimants and administering and amending the claims of 12,200 existing claimants when their circumstance change or when reviews are required. Invoicing and recovery of Overpayments of Housing Benefit.

Residents, businesses and the Council require efficient, good quality services. It is hoped that the bidders will be able to deliver the services for less than the current cost of £3.8 million per annum, by implementing processes and systems where customers are able to answer many of their own queries and update their own accounts with information on moves, discounts and other changes in their circumstances. The successful bidder will employ and manage staff and provide and procure the systems needed to administer these services. They will also provide Customers Services for the services, by answering telephone calls for those individuals who are unable to use any self-service systems or with enquiries that are more detailed. Full details relating to the Services are provided in the tender documents.

To participate, Suppliers will need to Register as a Supplier with ProContract, www.supplyingthesouthwest.org.uk, then Register an Interest before obtaining access to the tender documents. In the event of difficulties registering as a supplier, please refer to the System Administrator Proactis support team ProContractSuppliers@proactis.com

Contract Period
The contract will be initially for a period of 10 years commencing 1st April 2023 with the option to extend for a further 2 years as per the contract terms and conditions. 

Tender Responses
Tender Responses are required to be submitted no later than 24th January 2022, 1200 (noon) hrs  UK Local time via ProContract tender portal  - https://www.supplyingthesouthwest.org.uk/

Tender Clarifications
If you require any clarifications on the tender documents, please submit these in writing via Messaging in ProContract tender portal by 17th December 2021, 1200 (noon) hrs UK Local time. The Council's responses to these clarification questions will be uploaded periodically on the ProContract tender portal. 

Please note that this project has been advertised on Find a Tender Service, Contracts Finder / other web portals, however, Supplying the South West Portal, https://www.supplyingthesouthwest.org.uk/ is the only portal that includes all the relevant documents required to respond to this opportunity, bearing Project Id: DN579867

No Tender submissions will be considered without completing the tender documents in full including attachments and returning them

Title: PC REQUIREMENTS FOR NEW FACUTLY OF ARTS AND HUMANITIES BUILDING
Description:
This tender is for the desktop PC requirements for the new Faculty of Arts and Humanities building which opens for teaching and learning in September 2022. To achieve this opening date the equipment being tendered for will required to be delivered to our campus in two phases. The first phase of delivery is expected to be required from 25th July to 26th August 2022. The second phase is expected to be required from 17th October to 11th November 2022. These dates will be confirmed post contract award.

As well as supply of the equipment, services will be required to deliver and deploy equipment to desks and carry out the physical installation of the equipment. This will be for new equipment supplied as a result of this tender and for existing equipment that will be decanted into the new building by the University.

This is a competitive procurement, conducted as a call off against the: National Desktop and Notebook Agreement (NDNA) run by London Universities Purchasing Consortium (LUPC); Lot 3 'One Stop Shop' under the Public Contract Regulations 2015. Only suppliers listed under this agreement will be permitted to submit a tender response. Please note that Coventry University is prepared to accept bids from nominated multiple resellers on behalf of Coventry University.

Title: National Highways Knight Frank L&P 2021-22
Description:
We are engaging an auditor's expert to assist in auditing the detailed valuations underpinning the National Highways land and property provision. The specific work required is as follows:
• Review of VOA's methodology for calculating the land and property liabilities and confirmation that this is in line with the Compensation Code.
• Review of a sample of 5 valuations supporting land and property provisions to assess whether, based on the information provided in the detailed valuation, the key assumptions and judgements are materially consistent with the Compensation Code. In terms of providing a reasonable estimate for valuation on the anticipated forecast outturn cost to settle compensation. This should also confirm that the area of land included in the liability is appropriate. These valuations will, depending on sample selection, cover multiple properties (e.g. where they cover the acquisition area for a whole road scheme) and so some degree of consideration of items contributing to the overall valuation may be necessary in these larger samples, as opposed to them being tightly restricted to a single property. Regardless of item size, we would in each case be looking for the auditor's expert to assess the material reasonableness of the valuation in question. In the prior year, a review of 5 valuations were reviewed by our auditor's expert; this review will focus attention on a different sample of 5 land and property valuations. The initial contract period shall be to the end of the final audit period (July 2022), with an option to extend to cover subsequent audit cycles at the NAO's discretion.

Title: Guildhall Renewal Project - Architectural Services
Description:
The City of London Corporation's (CoL) corporate headquarters are the North and West Wings of the Guildhall. The CoL is exploring two main options for the future of the buildings. Option 1 is the phased refurbishment of the buildings to extend their economic life for the next c.20 years. Option 2, would look to undertake major works to the newly Listed Grade II West Wing to create a building which accommodates Member and officer activities as well as potentially refurbishing the adjacent Grade II Listed 20 Aldermanbury for an appropriate corporate purpose. In Option 2 the North Wing would be surplus to requirements, enabling the North Wing (where a Certificate of Immunity Against Listing was recently achieved)  to be demolished and replaced by a commercial building opportunity further north, defraying the cost of the West Wing works. It would also facilitate opening up a new public space to the rear of the Great Hall for the first time. 
The CoL at this point are looking to appoint for RIBA Stage 0 only with a further competition to the market for future stages.

Title: NECS396 - Crisis Alternative Service
Description:
North of England Commissioning Support (NECS) is a commissioning support service working for and on behalf of NHS Bradford District and Craven Clinical Commissioning Group (the CCG) to commission a Crisis Alternative Service:

The contract will be for 
•	2 years initial contract period with a possible 12 month extension period; 
Optional extension will be at the discretion of the Contracting Authority and subject to satisfactory financial and contractual performance and available funding.

This procurement process will mirror that of the Open procedure as in compliance with the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (as amended) in respect of Health Care Services under the Light Touch Regime, Regulations 74 - 76 and the National Health Service (Procurement, Patient Choice and Competition) (No. 2) Regulations 2013.  

Under the Public Services (Social Value) Act 2012 Contracting Authorities must also consider:

(a) how, what is proposed to be procured, might improve the economic, social and environmental well-being of the area where it exercises its functions, and

(b) how, in conducting the process of procurement, it might act with a view to securing that improvement. 

Accordingly, the subject matter of the contract has been scoped to take into account the priorities of the Contracting Authority relating to economic, social and environmental well-being.

Additional Information

Potential providers are to note that the Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations 2006 (as amended) may apply to this procurement including the New Fair Deal non-statutory policy setting out how pensions issues are to be dealt with when staff are compulsorily transferred from the public sector to independent providers delivering public services.

NECS is utilising an electronic tendering tool to manage this procurement and communicate with potential providers. There will be no hard copy documents issued to potential providers and all communications with NECS, including your submission, will be conducted via the portal.

https://in-tendhost.co.uk/nhsnecsu/aspx/Home
It is free to register on the portal, which can be accessed at any time of day.  
Should you have any queries, or are having problems registering on the portal, you should contact the e-Tendering provider by Email: support@in-tend.com or by phone on 0844 2728810
Helpdesk Availability - Monday to Friday 8:30am to 5.00pm.

Note all bidders will be required to submit their ITT responses by the deadline provided within the tender documents by 12 noon 21 January  2022

N.B. Due to currently proposed legislation which may mean that the current responsibilities of CCGs will transfer into Integrated Care Systems with effect from 01 March 2022, the ultimate commissioner for this contract may change.

Title: Provision of a National Evaluation Framework
Description:
Through this tender process, HEE is seeking to secure a diverse, highly skilled, and agile framework of evaluators to ensure that its projects, programmes, interventions, and investments are (here after referred to as "delivery activities") measured, proportionate and outcomes are ready to be appropriately shared. 

The National Evaluation Framework (herein after referred to as the 'NEF') will constitute a wide range of individuals and organisations (evaluators) with a broad range of expertise in evaluation processes and techniques - available to provide targeted support for the design and/or delivery of international, national, regional, and local workforce delivery activities across England. 

The expertise of the NEF will be commissioned via a formal procurement framework such that it will allow for flexible and responsive contracting to deploy appropriate knowledge, skills, and evaluation expertise - as, when and where required.

Title: Mental Health Support Teams in West Essex
Description:
The publication of Transforming Children and Young People's Mental Health provision green paper in December 2017 announced the establishment of Mental Health Support Teams who will work with schools to strengthen support for CYP with mental health issues.  The local MHST's will address the needs of children and young people by:

-	Delivering evidence-based interventions in or close to schools and colleges for those with mild to moderate mental health issues.
-	Helping children and young people with more severe needs to access the right support.
-	Working with and within schools and colleges, providing a link to specialist NHS services.
-	Building on and increasing support already in place, rather than replacing it.

The roll out is in line the NHS Long Term Plan that builds on the Five Year Forward View with a 10-year commitment to improve mental health services in adults and children in England.

Mind in West Essex have been awarded a contract to support the West Essex footprint.  

Mind in West Essex are a key provider of community based mental health services across West Essex.  They work with children and young people in order to foster a positive attitude to mental health early in life.  West Essex Mind will work with secondary schools to deliver the service having already in place strong relationships with the Essex early intervention / specialist Children's and Adolescent Mental Health Services (CAMHS) Provider - North East London NHS Foundation Trust (NELFT) to ensure the greatest success and impact for our children and young people.

This is a 2-year contract which began on 1st April 2022 and will expire on 31st March 2024.  Ahead of contract expiry, the Hertfordshire and West Essex Integrated Care System will review the services in place and make a further decision on the collaborative commissioning and procurement arrangements for the HWE ICS beyond 1st April 2024.
Contact Address 1: Building 4 Spencer Close, St Margaret's Hospital, The Plain
Supplier [Name|Address|Ref type|Ref Numb: [West Essex Mind|The Wellbeing Centre, 10-11 Corner House, Bushfair, Harlow, CM18 6NZ|NONE_OTHER||Yes|Yes]

Title: Construction works and Associated Services 2 / Procure 23 (CWAS2/P23)
Description:
Crown Commercial Service (CCS) as the Contracting Authority has put in place ProCure23 (P23) (Lots 1, 2 and 3) which is the fourth generation of the ProCure framework and will continue the provision of design and construction services to NHS capital projects other than in respect of the New Hospital Programme*. Please note this is available only to NHS bodies in England.

In its 19 year history this mature and award winning framework has successfully delivered more than 1200 projects across England, with a cumulative spend of £9.7bn, and ProCure23 will build this heritage into a third decade.

* Whilst the framework is not intended to provide the main sourcing routes for new hospitals within the New Hospital Programme (NHP), for the avoidance of doubt, NHP does reserve the right to use it. This reserved right was stated in the PIN.


Crown Commercial Service (CCS) as the Contracting Authority has put in in place a Pan Government Collaborative Agreement (for Lot 4 and Lot 5 only) for the provision of Construction Works to be utilised by eligible Central Government Departments and all other UK Public Sector Bodies, including Local Authorities, Health, Police, Fire and Rescue, Education and Devolved Administrations. This commercial agreement will be the recommended vehicle for all Construction Works projects required by UK Central Government Departments.

Title: con_13716 - SAFE (Support, Attend, Fulfil, Exceed) Taskforce - RM6187 Management Consultancy (MCF3)
Description:
We require the provider to work with DfE to design a programme of support and training for the SAFE taskforces on commissioning of interventions and services to tackle serious violence and improve engagement in education, including:

· Training for the leads to improve their commissioning capability
· Courses on how to use evidence to support decision making
· Training on outcomes-based commissioning
· Local coaching for commissioning leads
· Training on how to use the voice of the community and ensure interventions are 
 suitable for their context
· Training on how to oversee and monitor commissioned services
· Any other types of training and support that the provider would recommend and DfE agrees is suitable.

The provider will then provide the training, support and advice to SAFE taskforces as required, from 11th April 2022 to 31 March 2025.

This is likely to include an initial period of intense training and support to the taskforces at the outset of the programme (April to December 2022) followed by ongoing support to taskforces as and when it is required.

The provider will also be required to work with our evaluators to provide context and information on commissioning within the local areas, and to give regular updates on their delivery against a set of KPIs which will be developed following an initial period of discussion with the provider about how they will provide the above support.

Title: Provision of a Freedom of Information, SARs and Complaints System
Description:
Hampshire County Council receives circa 3000 FOI/SARs requests and Complaints annually.  Currently these requests are logged onto Access databases and spreadsheets.  The Authority wishes to streamline and automate the management of requests and complaints with a view to improving compliance, decreasing case time and reducing the administrative burden of receiving and distributing these requests.  

HCC needs a more "systemised", less manual solution that logs requests and then automatically reminds users that a response is required.  The system needs to be configurable to follow HCC workflows for the administration of different types of information request. As the system will contain personal data it needs to be secure, hosted in the UK and must be supported.

Title: The People Hub Skills for Growth Training Provider Framework
Description:
Corserv on behalf of Cornwall Development Company (CDC) and Cornwall Council is seeking to source and appoint suitably qualified training providers to deliver training to The People Hub Skills for Growth Project participants.

Following a successful application to the European Social Fund, CDC's The People Hub has secured European Social Fund and Cornwall Council investment to deliver the Skills Support for Growth Project located in Cornwall and The Isles of Scilly.

The total value of this opportunity is up to £500,000. It is intended that this will be spread across several suppliers according to the overall requirements, and the Applicant's capacity. As such Applicants are encouraged to bid for only the elements that they are capable and have the capacity to provide. The People Hub (CDC) Skills for Growth will offer qualifications at any accredited level, including basic skills.

The intention is to appoint up to 10 training providers based on 25% Price, 60% Quality and 15% Social Value.

This project has been part-financed by grant funding from the European Social Fund and will be subject to conditions imposed by the funding body. Suppliers will be expected to comply with the relevant requirements and any associated regulations such as procurement, publicity, and eligibility criteria.

Organisation Name: Surrey and Borders Partnership NHS Foundation Trust
Title: Payroll and Pension Service
Description:
The service will be provided:
Monday to Thursday 8.30am to 5.00pm
Friday 8.30am to 4.00pm
Staff may be available earlier or later than the times specified.

Background
NHS Payroll Services is hosted by Northumbria Healthcare NHS Trust. The Service is accountable to the Director of Finance, Northumbria Healthcare NHS Trust.
This services Schedule defines the services, which are delivered by Payroll Services in respect of the contract for the provision of payroll and associated services. It also sets out the respective roles and responsibilities of Payroll Services and the Trust in facilitating and 
undertaking the delivery of those services.

Payroll Procedures
Payroll Services will adhere to procedures in respect of all processes associated with implementation and the responsibilities relating to the Service Level Agreement.

Trust Procedures
The Trust will adhere to procedures in respect of all processes associated with implementation and the responsibilities relating to the Service Level Agreement.

Trust Standing Financial Instructions (SFI) 
Trust SFI's will be adhered to by both the Trust and Payroll Services, where these documents are made available. Both parties will at all times operate to accepted professional practice in the performance of this service and will be subject to regular audit.

Local Terms and Conditions of Service
The Trust will supply to Payroll Services local documented agreements that affect pay, including locally agreed policies and procedures. Further additions or amendments will be 
supplied to Payroll Services.
Payroll Services will operate in line with nationally agreed terms and conditions together with local agreements. 

Controls Assurance.
Payroll Services processes will meet the requirements of the both Statutory and NHS requirements.

Title: Northern Area Clearance (Zone 3, Zone 4 and TBWRF / FPP) Works for the North London Heat and Power Project - AWARD
Description:
The Authority is procuring this contract under the CCS Construction Works and Associated Services Framework Alliance Contract (RM6088).
      
      The works being procured are referred to as the Northern Area Clearance (Zone 3, Zone 4 and TBWRF / FPP ) Works.
      
      The works area comprises a former bulky waste recycling facility (BWRF) and fuel preparation plant (FPP) located in Zone 3, a small number of ancillary buildings located in Zone 4 and a temporary bulky waste recycling facility and fuel preparation plant (TBWRF / FPP). The works area is located within the Edmonton EcoPark site, a large, operational waste management facility.
      
      The scope of works includes the following main items:
      
      • Handover of the site from the Operator.
      • Sequencing and phasing of the site clearance works.
      • Site establishment and set-up.
      • Pre-works surveys
      • Enabling/preparatory works.
      • Utilities location, isolation, disconnection and protection.
      • Site clearance to remove required above and below ground structures.
      • Recycling of site-won material, including on site-processing and stockpiling of
      materials suitable for re-use.
      • Post-works condition surveys, reporting and provision of information.
      • Site handover back to the Operator.

Title: Contract 33 - Framework for Combined Drainage Works 2022-2024
Description:
The Authority invites suitably experienced providers for the above Framework for skilled service to provide a combined, Housing and Non-Housing, Drainage Works 2022-2024. This Framework Contract will ensure availability of skilled Contractors to deliver planned, programmed and responsive workse requiring differing values and complexities as required for the Framework Contract. The Framework contains two lots covering Lot 1 - Housing and Lot 2 Non-Housing and is initially for 2 years with an option, at the sole discretion of the Authority, to extend for up to a further 2 x 12 months. Details of the two Lots and operation of the Framework are included in the Tender pack.
The Authority will be acting as Principal Contractor and the Successful Contractor(s) will be acting as Sub-Contractors.
Successfully awarded Contractors will be required to work together with North Tyneside Council (the Authority) to drive improvements and support the aims and ambitions of the Contract.
The main areas of activity may comprise of, but are not exclusively limited to carrying out the following: 
                                        
Lot 1 = North Tyneside Council Housing Stock including carry out repairs to lead water pipe renewals, CCTV Surveys, drain cleaning/jet washing, drain lining repairs with any necessary associated works.
Lot 2 = North Tyneside Council Non-Housing and public Buildings Stock including carry out unblocking drains, doing CCTV surveys and septic tank disposal

Following this tender exercise, it is envisaged that up to 3 Contractors will be appointed to Lot 1 and the highest ranked Bidder will be offered the first ranked Contractor as a Direct Award for works up to £5K and for Lot 2 up to 5 Contractors will be appointed to the Framework, will be offered each contract under the value of £5,000, and each contract which is classified as urgent or an emergency (irrelevant of cost). If the first placed Contractor is unable to undertake or refuses the contract offer, then the contract will be offered to the next placed Contractor and so-forth, for works over £5K, a mini competition will be undertaken between the successful contractors, please refer to the Authority Requirements in the full tender pack for further information. The Tender documents are available to download immediately after registering an interest.  Tenders will only be accepted via the NEPO Portal, information is provided in additional information.
Additional Text:
Duration

Title: Temporary staffing support to the NHS breast screening restoration programme
Description:
The authority requires a new stage of work to further develop the restoration plan and support rapid implementation. The backlog has now been significantly reduced, this has revealed but a minority of Breast Screening Offices (BSOs) are not making progress and require intensive support. The new stage of work will continue the provision of analytic support (partially compensating for vacancies) but will contain new elements of tailored support to struggling BSOs and developing work systems that can be handed over to substantive employees.

Title: Early Intervention & Rehabilitation Service for Adults with Loss of Vision & Visual Impairment
Description:
Bury Council are seeking a suitably qualified and experienced organisation to provide an early intervention & rehabilitation service for adults with loss of vision & visual impairment in Bury.

The service will help to deliver the Bury Adult Social Care Vision by ensuring that adults with complete or nearly complete loss of vision and visual impairment receive support and information to enable them to be active members of the community.

The service will also support the delivery of the Care Act (2014), together with current national guidance and strategies or any future legislation issued by Government during the lifetime of the contract.

The contract will commence on 1st April 2022 to 31st March 2024 with the option to extend for up to a further 12 months.

If you wish to express an interest in this opportunity please visit The Chest e-tendering portal at www.the-chest.org.uk locate this opportunity and click the Login and register interest in this opportunity button. Once you have registered your interest you will be able to access the tender documentation.

The closing time and date for completed tender submissions, via The Chest, is 12 noon on Friday 21st January 2022.

Title: Film & Digital Programme Manager
Description:
The Film and Digital Programme Manager will provide Arts Connect and the creative and cultural sector in the West Midlands region with a Film and Digital Media Development Programme that supports their work with children and young people. 

Our aim is that through this programme the creative and cultural sector in the West Midlands are confident in developing ambitious new creative approaches to their work with film and digital media with children and young people.

We want to engage a supplier who can provide high quality, creatively ambitious film and digital media knowledge and expertise that will inform the development of a support programme for arts and cultural sector learning and engagement professionals.

The supplier will be creatively ambitious for their work and comfortable in a leadership role. They will have good communications skills and experience of working in and developing partnerships. They will be able to demonstrate a track record of leading digital development in the sector and successful delivery of support programmes for those with limited knowledge of film and digital media and for those with in depth knowledge and experience.

Commission Budget
The budget for this study has been set at a maximum of £22,100 excluding VAT, this includes travel expenses.
 
Mandatory Requirements
There are a number of Mandatory Requirements as part of this tender process, Tenderers must have/meet all mandatory requirements in order to bid for this tender. These are detailed in the Scoring Methodology documentation are scored on a Pass/Fail basis.

Contract Duration	
The term of the Contract shall be for a period of one (1) year commencing 1st April 2022 with an optional extension of up to an additional 36 months.

Closing Date 
Closing date and time for RFQ to be submitted via electronic portal is the 4th March 2022, 4pm.

The RFQ documents can be located on the following link, https://wlv.bravosolution.co.uk

Title: CP210-22 Connecting the Culm - Managing Big Problems in Small Places - part of the Flood and Coastal Resilience Innovation Programme
Description: This commission will focus primarily on modelling and analysis to develop catchment-based flood resilience activities. There are three elements to this: - Refining and communicating interventions to improve resilience within 6 sub-catchments identified as a priority for MBPiSP WP1 activities; - Informing the Culm Garden Village development to embed wider catchment resilience in the master-planning, design and delivery of this development; - Finalising the catchment-wide modelling and analysis to show the big picture of what resilience benefits are possible at a catchment scale, quantify these and the costs to deliver them.

Title: 3104/JN - Pulsed Optical Parametric Oscillator for SWIR Wavelengths
Description:
The University of Sheffield's Department of Physics and Astronomy, with funding from EPSRC (Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council), require a tuneable optical parametric oscillator (OPO) (1200 - 1600 nm) which will be pumped by an existing femtosecond Ti:Sapphire (Ti:S) laser system. The OPO output will be used for optical spectroscopy of semiconductor-based photonic devices. The primary use of the OPO will be for time-resolved resonant and quasi-resonant spectroscopy of quantum dots emitting in telecom wavelength regions.

This is an open exercise. The ITT can be downloaded by registering and expressing your interest on the University`s e-tendering system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/sheffield

This contract is for the development of an online training course on the topic of "Enhancing preparedness and detection of One Health threats in Vulnerable Communities and Interfaces", providing an overview of global animal health and food safety issues, risk assessment and management.

The course shall be delivered to forty (40) users based in Ghana, Bangladesh, Ethiopia and Nigeria.

Title: Provision of Tenancy Management Services: Hollybank Apartments
Description:
Oldham Council requires a Registered Provider of Social Housing to deliver tenancy management services for a 19-apartment supported housing scheme for adults with learning difficulties and complex needs. The scheme is located within the Limehurst Village area of Oldham. The tender is not Lotted and does not lend itself to lotting due to the quality of apartments. A single provider will be appointed. The estimated contract value stated above is exclusive of VAT. 

Tenderers must be a Registered Provider of Social Housing. . Please refer to the procurement documents for full details and other mandatory requirements.  A contract start date of 8th March 2022 is planned, and the contract will be offered on the basis of three years, with two further 12 month options to extend (maximum term of five years). 


Documents must be accessed and responded to via the Council's e-tendering portal: The Chest/Proactis (www.the-chest.org.uk). Project reference: DN586056. All communications must also be directed via this portal.

Title: (NU/1753) Supply of a Metrology System
Description:
The Driving the Electric Revolution (DER) is an Innovate UK (IUK) Challenge program to support UK industry to seize the economic opportunities from the global transition to clean technologies and electrification. The programme will help businesses across numerous sectors including transport, energy, construction and agriculture to invest and work together to capitalise on the UK's strengths in this technology.

The DER program vision is "To make the UK globally recognised as the centre of excellence in PEMD manufacturing processes".

As part of that program, Newcastle University has been awarded a large grant to establish a new DER Innovation Centre (DER-IC) in the North East of England. The NE DER-IC will concentrate on the prototyping and scale-up of power electronics and electric motors.

This document is focussed on the purchase of a Metrology System.

The scope is for the supply, delivery, and commissioning of each system as detailed in Section 3 of the ITT, with after sales support, a minimum 12 months parts and labour warranty and maintenance. This should include on completion of installation a complete set of operating and maintenance documents.

Title: Design Options for Nodal Pricing in GB
Description: This procurement is for a party to support and work alongside Ofgem in delivering a technical assessment of nodal pricing for GB.Ofgem is keen to investigate further the potential of nodal pricing in enabling a cost-effective, secure pathway to Net Zero for the whole energy system. Greater locational and temporal market signals have the potential to drive more efficient use of system assets and lower total system costs by:* incentivising optimal demand and supply responses (in the right place at the right time);* stimulating innovation in storage and demand response in the places it is needed; and* supporting competition between demand/storage solutions and new network capacity.

Title: (NU/1589-47) Driving the Electric Revolution Industrialisation Centres Website and Content Development
Description:
Following the launch of DER-IC project in 2020, an interim website was launched, hosted by a company called Icon at https://www.der-ic.org.uk which launched in March 2021. However, we are keen to create a more dynamic website which covers the breadth and scope of DER-IC and the work we do. We have purchased the domain www.der-ic.org.uk until June 2024. The current website is hosted until July 16th 2022. We have email addresses pointed to the domain, hosting for another year until June 2022.

We are seeking to appoint a supplier to work with DER-IC to build a new website, replacing the existing website and support it in the following years, until 31 March 2025 with an option for further support until 31 March 2030.

Title: SDF Lot 8 East_ Universal Sealants Ltd B
Description:
National Highways continues to roll out the Asset Delivery model to its operational areas. There is a
requirement to deliver a range of renewal, improvement and selected small scheme construction works on the
Strategic Road Network in areas utilising specialist contractors working collaboratively with National Highways
to deliver these works. It is envisaged that this framework will straddle two Road Investment Strategy (RIS)
periods (RIS 2 and RIS 3) enabling a smooth transition between them. Works for schemes have been divided
into a number of workstreams that align with the contractors' specialisms, and will also include design.
Bandings have been introduced into the framework model to differentiate some contracting terms between
bands.

This award is for Lot 8 Structures Waterproofing and Expansion Joints in the East region (National Highways Areas 6 and 8). 

This Lot covers the supply of materials, plant and labour for the installation of and repair work to;
- Highways structure expansion joints,
- Waterproofing systems,
- Testing of existing waterproofing systems, and
- Installation, maintenance and removal of any temporary works required to ensure a safe method of working

Other duties
This scope also includes:
- Mobilisation
- Early Contractor Involvement
- Welfare facilities
- Manage Network Occupancy
- Community; and
- Contingency
The scope may also include carrying out some of the duties of the Maintenance & Response Contractor and providing Incident Response (Rapid Response) when instructed.

Title: Emergency and Responsive Drainage Framework
Description:
Corserv on behalf of Cornwall Housing is seeking experienced and competent contractors to provide emergency and responsive residential and commercial drain clearing works.

The value of works within this framework is expected to be between £125,000 and £175,000 per annum. The intention is to appoint a single contractor for each lot, covering either the east or west areas of Cornwall. The initial term will be for two years with two optional one year extensions. 

The award evaluation criteria will be based on 30% Quality and 70% Price.

The Emergency and Responsive Drainage Framework may be used for other appropriate projects and requirements within the Corserv group of companies, including their statutory successors and wholly or partially owned organisations.

Title: Rock Drilling And Blasting Framework
Description:
Corserv on behalf of Cormac Solutions wishes to appoint a suitably qualified and experienced Contractor to carry out rock drilling and blasting works for quarry operations, via a framework agreement.

CORMAC Solutions manages a quarry at Castle-an-Dinas, Ludgvan, Penzance, Cornwall. The Quarry's primary function is to supply aggregates and surfacing materials to CORMAC Solutions and commercial contractors mainly in western and central Cornwall.

The value of works within this framework is expected to be between £150,000 and £200,000 per annum. It is intended that the majority of works packages will be called-off from a Schedule of Rates with individual values not generally exceeding £15,000.

The intention is to appoint the most economically advantageous tenderer (sole Contractor) based on 70% Price and 30% Quality.

Title: Community based cardiovascular disease support
Description:
This is a Contract Award Notice to communicate a contract award made by NHS North East Essex Clinical Commissioning Group (the CCG). 

The contract award is made to GP Primary Choice Ltd for the provision of community based cardiovascular disease support within North East Essex, for a 12 month period

This contract commences on 1st April 2022 until 31st March 2023, at a total contract value of £161,000.  

The CCG is publishing this Contract Award Notice in the Contracts Finder in accordance with the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (as amended by The Public Procurement (Amendment etc.) (EU Exit) Regulations 2020) for spend above £25,000. The Services in scope of this Contract Award Notice fall within social and other specific services within the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (as amended by The Public Procurement (Amendment etc.) (EU Exit) Regulations 2020), but the total contract value does not exceed the current threshold of £663,540.

This is a short term arrangement, and a future procurement may be conducted (pending the success of the pilot work).

Title: Evaluation of the Hamish Ogston Foundation Heritage Building Skills Programme - AWARD
Description:
Historic England (HE) is the public body that helps people care for, enjoy and celebrate England's spectacular historic environment. The support we give to others in the sector is a core part of our work, and as such 'build/develop sector capacity and capability to make the most of the historic environment' is a key activity in our current corporate plan (download at https://historicengland.org.uk/images-books/publications/he-corp-plan-2021-22/he-corp-plan-2021-22/). 
      We are commissioning this piece of work to find out more about the effectiveness of our flagship project to support the heritage construction sector in the north of England, the Hamish Ogston Foundation Heritage Building Skills Programme, hereafter the 'HOF Programme'.
