Title: PRN004370 Legionella Water Risk Assessment - AWARD
Description:
Nottinghamshire Fire & Rescue Service (NFRS) is seeking to appoint a contractor to undertake Water System Risk Assessments to the whole of the NFRS Estate in Nottinghamshire.
      
      The requirement is for the contractor to review the existing Water Risk Assessments and to provide an updated assessment of the risks arising from the NFRS water systems so that NFRS may effectively control and mitigate the risks, including, but not be limited to Legionella and other pathogens as well as consequential risks arising from the associated control measures. 
      
      This Risk Assessments will support NFRS in meeting its obligations and duties under the Health and Safety at Work Act 1974, Control of Substances Hazardous to Health Regulations 2002 and Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999
      
      Full details of this opportunity are contained within the RFQ (Request for Quotation) documentation, which will be available to download via the NFRS e-procurement portal In-Tend. via the following link:

Title: FS430936 FSA and Official  Controls: Research with  food business operators
Description:
This research falls under the Operational Transformation Programme (OTP) which aims 
to modernise the regulatory framework for the Official Controls. Food Business 
Operators (FBOs) in the meat, wine and dairy sectors all have a direct relationship with 
the Food Standards Agency (FSA) via its Official Controls, including inspections, 
enforcement, advice and guidance.
In 2020, the FSA piloted research to better understand the views that FBOs in England 
and Wales had of the FSA and Official Controls. This research explored several areas 
including overall views of the FSA, FBOs understanding of the FSA's role and purpose, 
what FBOs value about the FSA and criticisms, FBOs experience of certain FSA 
processes, ease of compliance with FSA guidelines and requirements and their 
satisfaction with FSA communications. The research consisted of both quantitative and 
qualitative interviews with wine and meat FBOs and quantitative interviews with dairy 
FBOs

The findings report 'FSA and Official Controls: Research with food business operators'
was published in July 2020. The findings from the quantitative part of this research will 
form a baseline for the research we are now commissioning.
The FSA would like to commission this research to understand the views that FBOs 
now have, to identify and monitor changes in these views over time and the impact of 
FSA initiatives. 
We are commissioning this research for three further waves to be conducted on a 
biennial basis in 2022, 2024 and 2026. There will be a break clause after each wave of 
research has been delivered to review the need for the research, the process and to 
ensure alignment with FSA priorities. 
As part of this contract, we require flexibility to be built in to allow for additional pieces of 
research to be conducted to address emerging research needs in this area (see 
methodology section below). Any additional/ ad hoc research requests will be funded 
separately from the biennial waves of research and will be discussed with the 
successful tenderer.
Attachments: FSA contract FS900203 Understanding the Food System Contract Signed_Redacted.pdf

Organisation Name: STAFFORDSHIRE AND LANCASHIRE COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: Waiting list prioritisation workshops and survey
Description:
Design and delivery of a deliberative engagement with members of the public in Coventry and 
Warwickshire, in order to discuss in detail the factors that should be considered when 
prioritising patients within an elective care waiting list and the relative weightings that should 
be assigned to these factors. The deliberative engagement comprises four workshops, each 
lasting for three hours, with 50 members of the public.
This will be followed by a national survey of 1,000 members of the public, conducted via the 
Ipsos KnowledgePanel. The survey will involve conjoint analysis to understand the relative 
weighting of different factors from a public perspective.

Title: SDF Lot 3.1 North_ Tarmac Trading Limited A
Description:
National Highways continues to roll out the Asset Delivery model to its operational areas. There is a
requirement to deliver a range of renewal, improvement and selected small scheme construction works on the
Strategic Road Network in areas utilising specialist contractors working collaboratively with National Highways
to deliver these works. It is envisaged that this framework will straddle two Road Investment Strategy (RIS)
periods (RIS 2 and RIS 3) enabling a smooth transition between them. Works for schemes have been divided
into a number of workstreams that align with the contractors' specialisms, and will also include design.
Bandings have been introduced into the framework model to differentiate some contracting terms between
bands.

This award is for Lot 3.1 Temporary Traffic Management (super region) in the North region (National Highways Areas 10, 12, 13 and 14).

This Lot covers the supply of materials, plant and labour for the;
- Design, installation, maintenance and removal of temporary traffic management
- Installation, maintenance and removal of temporary safety barrier systems
- Installation, maintenance and removal of temporary speed enforcement systems
- Installation, maintenance and removal of temporary CCTV systems.
- Management of breakdown recovery services
- Installation, maintenance and removal of temporary road markings and road studs, and
- Removal of existing road markings and road studs

Other duties
This scope also includes:
- Mobilisation
- Early Contractor Involvement
- Principal contractor
- Welfare facilities
- Manage Network Occupancy
- Community; and
- Contingency

Title: T0270 Understanding critical success factors for SRN transport interchanges
Description:
The objective of this project is to understand what the critical success factors are when considering transport Interchanges on the SRN.
The project will undertake a literature review to understand existing consultee advice provided to National Highways, provide insight into best practice from other countries and will highlight where there are gaps in our current understanding of what we need to successfully accommodate transport interchanges on the SRN.
The project will undertake workshops with National Highways colleagues and national managing demand stakeholders to understand our current position and where we could potentially link in with existing projects interacting with the SRN.
Learning will inform a plan to improve public transport on the SRN that will be implemented through RP3 in support of National Highways Net Zero Highways Plan.

Title: Improving Access to Psychological Therapies Services
Description:
The Provider will support the Commissioner in delivering a wide range of support provision for IAPT services to be delivered on behalf of East Riding residents. The Provider will deliver high quality IAPT interventions, using a variety of methods of engagement and delivery comprising a combination of some or all of the following: face to face, digital, telephone and text talk.

We are seeking a wide range of IAPT stepped care treatment pathways to be delivered by one single provider

How to Express Interest in this Tender:

1. Register your company on the eSourcing portal (this is only required once) - Browse to the eSourcing Portal: https://in-tendhost.co.uk/humbernhs/aspx/Home and click the link to register - Enter your correct business and user details - Note: your username will be the email address you have entered - you will also then shortly receive an email confirmation. Please note this is the new Trust portal if you have previously responded to tenders on the NOECPC intend portal you will ned to re-register on the Humber Teaching NHS Foundation Trust Portal https://in-tendhost.co.uk/humbernhs/aspx/Home

2. Once registered access the site and from the Home page hover over "Tenders" on the tool bar and select "current tenders" from the drop down options

3. Express Interest in the tender you are interested in - Select `Express Interest` within the Tender Details ( located at the bottom of the synopsis). On doing so, you will instantly have access to the Tender Management area for that tender. Any available documentation will be available via the various relevant tabs. You can access this area at any point by logging in, navigating to `My Tenders` and selecting 'View Details'.

4. Responding to the tender - There will be a tab allocated to any tender stage (e.g. PQQ and/or ITT). Under the `My Tender Return` area, you will be required to complete any mandatory questionnaires and upload any requested documentation. You can now use the `Correspondence` function to communicate with the buyer and seek any clarification (any clarifications will be found within the `Clarifications` tab). - Note the deadline for completion, then follow the onscreen instructions to complete and submit your response. - There may be a mixture of online and offline actions for you to perform (there is detailed online help available).

You must then submit your reply using the `Submit Response` button at the bottom of the page. If you require any further assistance please consult the online help, or contact the In-tend Support Desk. Alerts will be sent to your request email addresses when any correspondence, alterations or clarifications are issued.
Contact Address 1: Willerby Hill,  Beverley Rd, Nr Hull

Title: Contract 81 - Framework for Periodical Electrical Inspections 2022-2024
Description:
The Authority invites suitably experienced providers for the above Framework for skilled service to provide Periodic Electrical Inspections 2022-2024. This Framework Contract will ensure availability of skilled Contractors to deliver the Planned and Programmed Service requiring differing values and complexities as required for the Framework Contract. The Framework is initially for 2 years with an option, at the sole discretion of the Authority, to extend for up to a further 2 x 12 months. Details of the operation of the Framework are included in the Tender pack.

The Authority will be acting as Principal Contractor and the Successful Contractor(s) will be acting as Sub-Contractors.

Successfully awarded Contractors will be required to work together with North Tyneside Council (the Authority) to drive improvements and support the aims and ambitions of the Contract.

The main areas of activity may comprise of, but not exclusively be limited to carrying out pwriodic electrical Inspections and providing an Electrical Condition Report (EICR) in accordance with BS7671 - Requirements for Electrical Installations (IET Wiring Regulations) on the North Tyneside domestic Housing Stock.

A full address schedule will be provided to the successful contractor prior to commencement, and it is estimated around 700-800 properties per year will be inspected. Applicant must have either NICEIC or NAPIT accreditations to provide these works.

Following this tender exercise, it is envisaged that 3 Contractors will be appointed to the Framework. Works, the highest ranked Bidder will be offered the first ranked Contractor as a Direct Award for works up to £1K, for works over £1K, a mini competition will be undertaken between the 3 successful contractors, please refer to the Authority Requirements in the full tender pack for further information. The Tender documents are available to download immediately after registering an interest.   Further information to access the documents is in additional information.

The Documentation is available to access and download immediately once organisations have registered their interest in this opportunity ONLY via the ProContract electronic Tendering Portal, the link to the, website is provided further below The link to North Tyneside Councils Tender opportunities is provided
Links: https://procontract.due-north.com/Opportunities/Index?resetFilter=True&applyFilter=True&p=1c9e782c-541e-e611-8114-000c29c9ba21&v=1 Unregistered bidders will be redirected to a registration page, registration is free.
Additional Text:
The initial contract is for twenty four months with an option to extend for up to a further two twelve month periods after which renewals will be undertaken in accordance with the Authority's contract Standing Orders,.
The Documentation is available to access and download immediately once organisations have registered their interest in this opportunity ONLY via the ProContract electronic Tendering Portal, the link to the, website is provided further below

Title: PROVISION OF DRIVER TRAINING FOR BRITISH FORCES CYPRUS (BFC)
Description:
The Authority has a requirement is for a 3 (three) year contract to provide driver training services to British Forces Cyprus (BFC) on a call off basis. BFC have a Defence Licensing and Testing Authority (DELTA) set up to Co-ord the training, this is in line with Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) the Ministry of Defence (MOD) have agreed with the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency and the Delta Inspectorate. This requirement is to provide full category B, B+E, C, C+E and D1 driver training to personnel within BFC.
Driving instructors shall be fully qualified and meet the standards required. Instructors may be subject to a MOD assessment in the following areas:
Driving ability
Instructional ability, including teaching, manoeuvring and trailer uncoupling
Identification and rectification of student driver errors.
The Authority will provide all vehicles

Title: IT Solution
Description:
Triggered by new ways of working since the onset of Covid 19 in 2020, the Healthcare Quality Improvement Partnership (HQIP) are seeking to review their Information Technology (IT) strategy.

As a business, HQIP aims to improve health outcomes by enabling those who commission, deliver and receive healthcare to measure and improve healthcare services. HQIP is responsible for several national healthcare quality improvement programmes, including running the National Joint Registry (NJR) and managing and commissioning the National Clinical Audit and Patient Outcomes Programme (NCAPOP) on behalf of NHS England, the Welsh
Government and in some cases other devolved authorities. 

It is therefore strategically important that HQIP has an effective, efficient but ultimately fit for purpose IT Infrastructure that meets the business current needs and offers flexibility to meet the needs of the future.

This contract has the potential to extend for a further 2 years in increments of 12 months (2+1+1)

Title: Breastfeeding Support Service
Description:
The Breastfeeding Support Service is being commissioned by Public Health Dorset for an initial contract period of three years commencing 01 June 2022, plus an option to extend for a further two years, making a potential total contract period of five years, ending 31 May 2027.

The area to be covered by the Service incorporates the geographical regions covered by Dorset Council and Bournemouth, Christchurch, Poole Council.

The aims of the service are:
•	To develop and maintain a breastfeeding support service that helps mothers to continue to breastfeed to at least 6-8 weeks.
•	To contribute to addressing health inequalities by offering targeted support for mothers least likely to continue breastfeeding, including those aged under 25 years.
•	To build community capacity and ability through the recruitment of breastfeeding support volunteers and staff.
•	To create a diverse mix of volunteers and staff, which may include those who have not recently breastfed. 
•	To provide training, support and supervision to volunteers and staff.

Full details may be found and any tender bid submitted, via: www.supplyingthesouthwest.org.uk

Title: SCC - XA - RFQ - Hunger for Skills: Employer demand for skills and talent
Description:
Surrey County Council is working in partnership with the Surrey Skills Leadership Forum to provide a strategic vision for the skills system in Surrey. It has representative members from business, providers, inclusion, local authority and LEPs. The Forum was established in December 2021, with focus on developing and overseeing the implementation of a Local Skills Improvement Plan (LSIP) for Surrey. The research outlined in this RFQ will form a critical part of the evidence that will underpin the LSIP, particularly in terms of growth sector demand for employment and skills development.
      
      Hunger for Skills - An Economic Framework for Demand in Surrey. The scope of this commission is to research and develop a framework for future skills demand, within Surrey's growth sectors, in collaboration with local employers and industry experts.

Title: School Cycle Training
Description:
To deliver cycle training and cycling related services for school aged children. The contract is contingent on funding received from TfL or/and funding secured from other successful bids in which the council submits.

The core aim of the school cycle training programme is to ensure that as many ten (10) and eleven (11) year old children in the borough can cycle safely on road by achieving Bikeability Level 1 & 2 in line with National Bikeability Guidelines.

A secondary aim of the programme is to get more children making trips by bike, especially on the journey to and from school. We currently train approximately 1600 children in 44 of LBH primary schools with a potential to work in more primary schools, this training is carried out through the school year with greater numbers of children being trained in the autumn and summer terms.

To achieve this, we seek a Contractor to deliver Bikeability training levels one (1) and two (2) combined in LBH primary schools for years six (6) by accredited trainers. This tuition will follow the National Bikeability Delivery Standards. Should include a preliminary check of bicycles or a Dr Bike to be carried out before the start of training at schools with a three (3) or more class intake per year.

Title: Connexus Heating Compliance Audits Tender
Description:
Connexus Homes Limited is a Social Landlord delivering Gas Service, Maintenance and Installations in house with the support of contractors.
We have 10,800 properties of which 7859 have domestic gas (natural gas and LPG), 43 have commercial heating systems, 288 have oil, 552 have solid fuel, 729 have renewable technology and the remainder are all electric.
We have an in-house Heating Team with 24 registered gas engineers, some of whom are oil, renewable and solid fuel qualified.  We also use a number of subcontractors to support all elements of this work.
We contract out all of our Commercial Heating work to a contractor.
Heating Servicing, Maintenance and Installations are completed predominantly by an in-house heating team, with the support of a number of subcontractors.
We are looking to appoint an independent 3rd Party Auditor, with the sole purpose of giving the organisation ongoing feedback on the safe working of all its in-house engineers work, and that of employed contractors and sub-contractors.  This feedback will be used by us to improve standards, training and support to our engineers and staff.

Title: CONSULTANT TO PROJECT MANAGE TEST AND LEARN PROJECTS
Description:
Purpose of this Brief
a.    The Bedford Arts & Cultural Education Partnership (BACE) wishes to commission suitably qualified and experienced consultant(s) to project manage the delivery of, and evaluate and report on, a series of Test & Learn projects commissioned by schools in Bedford Borough, which provide high quality arts and cultural learning opportunities for pupils.

b.    The contract will be managed by University of Bedfordshire (Lead Organisation). The work is commissioned by the BACE Steering Group, who will select the successful bidder and monitor the 
delivery of the contract. The successful bidder will be expected to report regularly to the BACE Steering Group during the course of the contract.

c.    The work must recognise BACE Year 2 Programme aims, objectives and outcomes.

2.   Context
a.    BACE was formed in 2017 to act as the Cultural Education Partnership for Bedford Borough and deliver on the Arts Council England Cultural Education Challenge.

b.    Bedford Arts and Cultural Education (BACE) is a network of leaders from the arts, culture and education sectors within Bedford Borough who have committed to work in partnership and to align 
resources to ensure that children and young people, who are currently underserved, have access to high quality opportunities for meaningful engagement with and learning through arts and culture.

c.    The Partnership currently consists of a Steering Group made up of representatives from local early years and primary education (Bedford Nursery Schools), independent schools (The Harpur 
Trust), FE/HE (University of Bedfordshire), cultural providers (Bedford Creative Arts, Full House Theatre, the Philharmonia Orchestra, Bedfordshire Museum Development), and the Local Authority (Libraries & Culture, School Improvement, Bedford Music Hub).

d.    BACE intends to form an Executive Board, consisting of senior leaders drawn from the education and cultural sectors, and from the Local Authority. It is envisaged that this Board will also oversee the Bedford Cultural Partnership, a group of organisations leading on the development of a Cultural Strategy for Bedford Borough.

e.    BACE has completed a Year 1 Programme, a Twinning project between Bedford Borough Schools and cultural providers, with the support of Education Improvement Support Grant funding.

f.     The funding for this contract and the wider work being undertaken as part of CE Year 2 Programme is from Royal Opera House Bridge Partnership Investment.
Additional Text: You need to register and express an interest in the tender on the University's Procurement website: https://www.in-tendhost.co.uk/universityofbedfordshire/aspx/Home

Title: Support (under the Rough Sleeping Accommodation Programme) for Roundhayes, Wemouth
Description:
The Council seeks a partner with a track record of providing trauma informed and person-centred support to individuals with medium support needs in self-contained accommodation. 

The aim of the project is to give people 'their own front door' providing stable accommodation with flexible support dependent on need; enabling individuals to develop the skills and motivation to maintain a tenancy and move on to permanent accommodation. 

The provider will be flexible and innovative in their approach to meet the needs of individuals. Acknowledging that progress within this group is often demonstrated by small but significant steps.

Support will address substance and alcohol misuse, offending behaviours, physical and mental health issues. The aim of this support is to prevent self -defeating behaviours, break the cycle of rough sleeping and sofa surfing thus creating a "no wrong door approach".   

Support workers will be experienced in psychologically informed practices. They will have the skills to build trusting relationships with service users and the local knowledge and expertise to link in with a wide range of services, including healthcare, mental health, substance misuse. They will also provide support to develop life skills such as budgeting, cooking, and ensure financial and digital inclusion. 

The provider will also provide an emergency on call out of hours service.

The marginalisation and stigmatisation of this group means it is essential the project works closely with the local community. 

The provider will support clients to contribute to the development of new and existing services.

The provider will attend Allocation Panel meetings which will consider referrals to the project and other accommodation funded by Next Steps Accommodation Programme (NSAP) and Rough Sleeper Accommodation Programme (RSAP).

Full details may be found, and any tender bid submitted, via the e-tendering portal: www.supplyingthesouthwest.org.uk

\r

\r

Organisation Name: Homes England (the name adopted by the Homes and Communities Agency)
Title: Homes England - DOS5 - Microsoft Partner for SharePoint Online Design, Configuration and Expert Support
Description:
This project will define, design, and configure SharePoint Online to support HE's business needs and our adoption of MS365. This includes design and configuring SharePoint Online to function as our agency wide DMS. The project will appoint a Microsoft Partner who can assist the organisation on this journey, by providing the guidance, expertise, support, and training needed. It will configure our tenancy and provided reusable artifacts including templates for SharePoint Online hub sites and working areas, libraries and lists, data feeds and connections, permission settings and governance policies. It will recommend and configure the Power Apps, Power Automate and the tools needed to support SPO users. It will provide Governance currently not in place, including around Data Retention, Data Loss Protection, and Data Classification (Labelling). It will migrate content and forms from SharePoint On-Prem and enable HE to decommission this legacy system and archive any content that needs to be retained in long term digital storage. It will provide the knowledge transfer and training to support this platform going forward.\r
Problems this project will solve\r
•	Lack of governance and control means Homes England MS365 tenancy exposes the organisation to risk beyond our appetite.\r
•	Lack of governance of the platform, security controls, taxonomy, labels and metadata, retention policy, and correctly configured Compliance Centre has prevented SharePoint Online being adopted as our Document Management System.\r
•	Lack of inhouse knowledge and skills means Homes England are not making most of the platform and the opportunities this provides. \r
•	Department head and programme leads are frustrated by not being able to use SharePoint Online as this has not been certified for a range of use, delaying both process change and efficiency improvements that the platform could support.

Title: Research Services - Assessing engagement with shareholders and reporting following significant votes against a resolution
Description:
***THIS OPPORTUNITY IS CLOSED. THIS IS A CONTRACT AWARD NOTICE***

The Financial Reporting Council (FRC) regulates auditors, accountants and actuaries and sets the UK's Corporate Governance and Stewardship Codes. We seek to promote transparency and integrity in business; our work is aimed at investors and others who rely on company accounts, audit and high-quality risk management. As the Competent Authority for audit in the UK, the FRC sets auditing and ethical standards and monitors and enforces audit quality.
This project concerns shareholder votes of 20% or more against resolutions at company Annual General Meetings (AGMs). We are interested in how such votes are reported and the level, and quality, of engagement that subsequently takes place between company boards and investors.


The aim of the research project was to assess: 

•	The level and quality of companies' reporting against Provision 4 of the Corporate Governance Code and the usefulness of this reporting to shareholders.
•	The level and quality of engagement between companies and their shareholders following a vote of 20% or more against a proposed resolution.
•	How this engagement has impacted companies' subsequent actions and subsequent shareholder stewardship, including engagement and voting.  
 
The research project supports the work of the Corporate Governance and Stewardship team in the FRC, as well as the broader aims of the FRC, to understand and promote good governance and best practice. The output from the research may be used in an FRC publication(s) and where this is the case the contribution of the contracted research team will be cited and acknowledged appropriately.

Scope of the Project
  
The research includes all companies that were constituents of the FTSE 350 index on 1 January 2019 and will cover all AGMs of those companies in 2019, 2020 and 2021.
 
Approach 
The data for this research is available from the following sources:
•	The Investment Association's public register
•	Companies' AGM notices
•	Companies' statements/updates/announcements (including those of AGM voting results)
•	Companies' annual reports
•	Other information sources (e.g. media coverage, stock exchange announcements, stewardship reports, dialogue with IA, etc). 

The successful bid established the criteria/scale to reliably assess:
•	Quality of reporting by companies in the areas listed
•	Quality of engagement between companies and shareholders
These criteria should allow for comparisons between companies and between time periods (within the scope of the research sample).
Attachments: 01 Research Services ITT.pdf 02 Tender Response Final.docx

Title: Fit-out services for The Innovation Platform Exhibition at the National Railway Museum and Locomotion - AWARD
Description:
The Innovation Platform will be a dedicated display where we will reveal one ground-breaking object from the contemporary rail industry at a time. It is a collective opportunity for the Science Museum Group and partners in the rail sector to showcase the latest and greatest in rail technology to the public. The Innovation Platform will provide a flexibly delivered visitor offer during masterplan construction works, which will take place across both museum sites for the duration of the project.
      
      The project will be ongoing for two years at each site. At the National Railway Museum, there will be twelve objects exhibited on a two-month rolling display. At Locomotion, there will be four objects exhibited, on a six-month rolling display. Object displays will be grouped into four Seasons: Autonomous Technology, Decarbonisation, Smart Cities and Communities.
      
      This invitation to tender is for the fabrication of the exhibition structures that will be used for all four Seasons at NRM and LCM, and the fit-out for Season 1 at NRM and LCM. Seasons 2-4 will be tendered separately at a future date.

Title: South Cambridgeshire District Council- Sport Pitches Inspection
Description:
The Council seeks a contactor to perform the following:
•	Inspect the new sport pitches at Western Park, Phase 1 Northstowe to ensure they meet the Sports Pitches Specification
o	The pitch sizes should meet the core criteria established by The Football Association, Sport England Design Guidance Notes and requirements of the National Governing Bodies.
o	All the grassed space should meet the required quality standards for sports turf as recommended by the National Governing Bodies. 
o	All artificial surfaces and floodlighting should be constructed to meet SAPCA and ILP standards. Floodlights carefully designed to minimise light pollution by selecting lighting that meets the criteria to localise luminance and confine it, as far as possible, to the pitches/courts.
o	Meet the National Governing Body standards in terms of design, dimensions, drainage, foundations, and construction. The pitches should be equipped to the Governing Body recommendations including provision of goals, fencing, posts and nets. 
o	The 3G STP to compile with The Football Association and World Rugby guidelines with a 60mm pile and in situ shockpad. The pitch size is to be 100m x 64 but added to that is a safety area around the pitch of 3m leading to a pitch size footprint of 106m x 70m. The FA recommended fence height on all sides of the STP is 4.5m. The STP to be floodlit to an average illuminance of > 200 lux min. 
o	The area allocated for the rugby grass pitch is 120m x 80m, which includes a 10m in goal area and a 5m run-off area for safety surrounding the pitch. 
o	The bowling green to be 6 rink and be 41m x 41m, including a ditch. 
o	A 2-court floodlit, formal MUGA with space for 1 tennis court, or 1 netball court, or 1 basketball court or 4 mini tennis courts with flexibility of each format. The MUGA to be constructed to the specifications of Sport England and the National Governing Bodies of the respective sports. 
•	The sports pitches which require inspecting are as follows:
o	1 x Synthetic Artificially Turfed Pitch (100m x 64m)
o	1 x Formal MUGA (37m x 34m)
o	2 x Mini Football pitches (each 55m x 37m)
o	2 x Junior Football pitches (each 91m x 55m)
o	1 x Senior Rugby Pitch (120m x 80m)
o	1 x Senior Football pitch (100m x 64m)
o	1 x Bowling Green (41m x 41m)

Organisation Name: NHS SOUTH OF ENGLAND PROCUREMENT SERVICES
Title: Stroke Recovery Service
Description:
This notice is to inform the market that the Contracting Authorities (NHS East Sussex CCG, NHS West Sussex CCG, NHS Brighton and Hove CCG) have now awarded a 1 year contract with a 1 year contract extension option to The Stroke Association. The proposed contract will commence on 1st April 2022. 

A Stroke Recovery Service is currently provided in Sussex by The Stroke Association. Each CCG has a slightly different scope of service, but each is in place to provide support by The Stroke Association to stroke survivors on discharge from hospital, assessment, review, education on life after stroke, links and sign-posting to grants, peer support and other community and voluntary organisations, and including in some places a formal six-month review post discharge.

There is a need to align current stroke recovery services with national Integrated Stroke Delivery Network (ISDN) guidance and requirements, however the establishment of the Sussex ISDN and its work has been delayed due to local and national Covid-19 response and priorities.

There is a need to ensure continuity and consistency of service across Sussex prior to the future re-commissioning. Commissioners and Sussex ISDN managers will work with providers to ensure these requirements are appropriately developed on a local basis, and the proposed extension of this contract will support this. The current provider is currently working with NHS England on ISDN guidance. By taking this direct award action an equitable service is being made available to all Sussex residents/patients

As part of this continuity of service, the West Sussex service will be extended into the North Coastal West Sussex area, and this is to be added to the current contract under the same scope, service specification, and KPIs, and will equalise the service provision in West Sussex while further work is taking place across the Sussex Health and Care Partnership and with the ISDN to ensure the service will be developed in line with national requirement as well as local patient need.

The Authority will enter into a contract with the incumbent provider to ensure continuity of services, because no response/no requests to participate have been submitted in response to the Prior Information Notice.
Additional Text:
Please note: NHS England and Improvement have announced that the Sussex Health and Care Partnership, which is made up of all health and care organisations across East Sussex, West Sussex, and Brighton and Hove, has successfully met the criteria to become an Integrated Care System (ICS). An ICS is a way of working across health and care organisations that allows them to work closer together, to take collective responsibility of the health and wellbeing of populations across large areas.

It is not anticipated that the statutory responsibility or accountability of the individual health and care organisations working as an ICS will be affected, save for the expectation that CCG organisations will be abolished and functions transferred to the ICS. As a result of these intended healthcare reforms, the Contracting Authorities, currently NHS West Sussex CCG, NHS Brighton and Hove CCG and NHS East Sussex CCG, may change during the life of the contract.
Refer to South of England Procurement Services to trigger the review process. This process can be further escalated to NHS Improvement or High Court of England and Wales.

Notice Identifier: Warslow Moors Estate Hydrological Survey at al
Title: Warslow Moors Estate - Orchard Common complex: Hydrological Survey at al
Description:
Hydrological Survey, Peat Depth Survey, Sphagnum Frequency survey, and Phase One Habitat Survey with the overall aim to identify and describe the hydrological context of the survey area, identifying opportunities to improve the local water quality and its water storage capabilities and in particular any opportunities for wetting up blanket bog and wet heath habitats in line with the conservation objectives of the SSSI, helping achieve favourable and wider conservation interest. 
Recommended interventions should aim to remove or mitigate the impacts of any artificial drainage features, such as moorland grips or drains and where possible:
•	Restore a more "natural" hydrological regime
•	Maximise opportunities for raising water levels in the peat
•	Strengthen the resilience of habitats such as blanket bog, wet heath, flushes and open water on the site
•	Benefit nesting waders, invertebrates and wetland plants in particular.

The survey should:
It should:
 •	Review existing data pertaining to drainage 
•	Undertake field survey of all hydrological features
 •	The phase 1 habitat maps should be reviewed and updated
 •	Sphagnum distribution and relative abundance 
•	Quantify peat depth across the survey area and any underlying mineral soils 
•	Record actual depth of materials
•	Identify and describe water inputs and related features to the site
•	Identify and describe water outputs from the site
